Fallout 3 – Game of the Year Edition   is a first-person open world post-apocalyptic RPG. After escaping from Vault 101, a subterranean nuclear fallout shelter you lived in all your life, you explore the post-nuclear war-torn wastelands of Washington DC while on the trace of your father's footsteps.   Pros:  1st person perspective is a huge departure from the original   Fallout   games that add to the immersiveness. The game offers a very large world to explore, filled with bandits, super mutants, ghouls and radioactive creatures. I love the bottle caps as currency, although you're likely to mostly barter for ammos and equipment in exchange for the incredible amount of scraps and junk you can scavenge. There's a nice amount of guns to get your hands on, drugs (or chems) to give you boosts, and an assortment of food and medicine to keep your health up, most of which is irradiated which forces you to carefully manage your radiation poisoning. Quests are plentiful, and everywhere you go you'll have people asking for help in these hard times. The RPG elements consists of your basic attributes and trained skills, while leveling up allows you to train those skills and assign perk points to an increasing list of perk options, so that you may make your character just the way you want it. The VATS system allows you do precision targeting in fights, with VATS points just limited enough to avoid over use.   Cons:  The world design is not on par with modern post-apocalyptic setting: wastelands feel barren and empty, buildings look and feel repetitive, and the urban DC area is nothing but impassable walls of concrete rubble with only the occasional building you can actually get in. Graphics and character designs feel repetitive and didn't age well. Gameplay does include a third-person option, but it's basically the same as the first-person option except that you see your character's back. Getting started can discourage newcomers as the early game is much harder and players spend most of their time going back and forth carrying junk with their limited carrying capacity to barter for barely as much ammos as they spent getting their loot, assuming the few vendors even have any stock of ammos compatible with the guns you have.   Verdict:  ★★★☆☆ - It's up to you  I'm threading lightly as not everyone will enjoy this game: it's not as lively as   Fallout 4  , not as deep as the   Metro   series, and doesn't have the personality of the   Borderland   series. If you're a classic Fallout fan looking for a modern take on the isometric cRPG style, you should probably be looking at   Wasteland 2  . Otherwise, this game and its DLCs will give you dozens upon dozens of hours of gameplay, so of course I recommend it!    P.S. : Those experiencing compatibility issues can fix this through the use of Mods. Unfortunately, these are not supported by Steam and installing an external 3rd party Mod manager will prevent this game from running normally through Steam. If   Star Wars | Knights of the Old Republic II: The Sith Lords   can have Steam Workshop support added a decade after release, I see no reason or excuse for   Bethesda   not to do the same with their original take on the  Fallout  franchise.  —————————————————————————   This was just my opinion.   If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated)  reviews .

Fallout 3 or Fallout New Vegas?  I see a lot of people asking about if they should play Fallout 3 first, or Fallout: New Vegas. I went through this dillemma myself. I chose to buy Fallout: New Vegas.  Let me first give you a brief summary about the two games: Fallout 3: You are a vault dweller. Your father has left the vault for an unknown reason. You go after him and enter the Capital Wasteland. You're main goal is to find your father again. Fallout: New Vegas: You are a courier who had to deliver a package, but in the middle of your journey you were shot in the head by a member of the Chairmen (one of the families of the Strip). You wake up after being healed by an old man and you track him down. There is also a war going on in the Mojave Wasteland between the NCR, the New California Republic which is a faction that works with laws and such as they did before the bombs fell, and Caesers Legion, a faction based upon the old Romian Empire which is build upon slaves.  There are two major differences in the two games. Fallout 3 is build upon the idea that you are fresh out of the vault. In the game, everything is new to you ánd your character. Fallout: New Vegas is not really build upon this idea. You were shot in the head and you start your journey from a little farmers town.  Fallout 3 has an interesting storyline which I really enjoyed. It feels more personal then in New Vegas. Fallout: New Vegas has a lot (and I mean a lot) of choices. The game is bigger than Fallout 3, because it has more quests.  I chose New Vegas because I wanted to have a lot of things to do in the game. But I now regret this decission. I think you should buy Fallout 3 first, it's a great beginning for Fallout games in general if you have never played one. You get all the basics early on in the game and your goal is pretty clear. If you already played Fallout 4, then I'd recommend you to buy Fallout: New Vegas.

Great game, great characters. However there are a few flaws.  The first one is it's legendary instability under Windows 7 or later. Depending on your setup, the game can be anywhere between unplayable and crashing at the title screen to playable, but with scrambled music due to the Directsound kerfuffle. Heck, even though the game is playable under Vista the soundtrack is scrambled albeit still fixable if you're willing to go out and buy a Creative gaming sound card if just to use ALchemy to fix the soundtrack. The biggest issue is that Bethesda is not willing to fix the bugs even though there is a huge fanbase, and is even working against the fans by issuing takedowns at unofficial patches to fix the issues. That's right, the developer doesn't want fans to play the game with proper music.   Secondly, the game uses the problematic Games for Windows Live framework for a lot of things, including copy protection. Microsoft recently announced that they're shutting down GFWL. Guess what this means for the game. Sure, again there are fanmade patches to work around this, but well, it shows Bethesda's mindset.  In short, unless you're willing to go the full mile securing a decent Windows XP machine and then get your hands dirty with unofficial patches, don't buy this. If you absolutely must, get one of the console versions instead, PC gaming master race be damned. Don't get me wrong- It's a great game, and I support both consoles and PCs equally, but the PC version of this game is just not worth it and I'm not happy with the way Bethesda is treating the PC players of this game.  EDIT: Just bought a new laptop and upgraded it to Windows 10. Won't run, period. The game installs, the Launcher comes up (along with a stern warning from Windows saying that this game won't run), and... nothing. Clicking on Play results in nothing happening. Additionally, the game's installation of Games for Windows Live bricked the laptop's internet connection until said item is uninstalled. It has went from bad to worse. I definitey don't recommend it now. It's a great game, but it's coding is so bad it's not even forwards compatible with newer versions of Windows.

I guess I should write a review about  the best RPG game I have ever played . Don't let my hours played fool you, I have played through the entire story and all DLC's on my playstation 3 a lot of times and still I haven't seen everything  (EDIT: I am also playing with mods currently so all the time I have played in the last month and everything I will play won't be counted (as of 19-3-2016)) .  Which brings me to my first 'Pro'    Pros:   - A HUGE amount of content , it is insane how much there is to do in Fallout 3. The map is big, there are a lot of places to discover, people to talk to, quests to do, items to find, computers to hack, locks to pick and enemies to shoot. A vast assortment of mods add a lot to this already amazing game!  - The story is good , its nothing special but it is good enough, the DLC's are also amazing and have their own stories!  - DLC done right , this isn't some cash grab DLC game, the DLC's add new items, enemies, lore and more to the game!  - Great atmosphere , the music is really good too!  - Your choices matter , the dialogue system is great, although the characters you talk to are a bit 'lifeless'.    Cons:   - Stiff NPC's/unrealistic animations , When you talk to someone they stand still like they are a tree, the animations aren't very good either.  - Graphics are very outdated , this isn't a con to me personnaly but it might throw some people off, ofcourse there are mods to make it look better!  - Bugs and glitches , sometimes funny, sometimes game breaking.   I recommend this game  because I think it is amazing, video games are truly a form of art.  Steel be with you!

Disclaimer: Long, and a side quest spoiler. TL; DR This game takes awhile to get exciting, but its well worth it.  Rather than discuss why I recommend this game, allow me to post a slight side quest spoiler, as it really captures the moment where I fell in love with Fallout 3.  As I was exploring the wastes, I came across a sizeable tower. As I neared this tower, I saw a Ghoul (ie looks like a Zombie but is in full control of his body/mind) aruging with someone over an intercom. Naturally I eavesdropped and discoverd the Ghoul wanted to bring his people into the tower, and the people in the tower, very clearly did not want them in.   So as the dismissed Ghoul left I naturally tried my hand at getting into the tower. As I was a human, they let me in no problem. Its there that I picked up a quest to eliminate the Ghouls, as they were become increasingly bothersome to the residents. So I ventured into the tunnels, and found the leader whom I saw previously yelling into the towers intercom. He proposed a different solution, one that would let him and his band of ghouls forcefully take over the tower.   I weighed my options. Most tower citizens were not bigots, so I saw no reason to kill them to let the Ghouls in, yet I did not want to elimite the Ghouls. Not agreeing with eliminating either party, I opted for a more peaceful route.  After a few speech persuasions, (maybe a few stealthy murders) I persuaded the majority of the citizens in the tower to let the Ghouls in. The ghouls moved in shortly after. All was well. I had done it. I had solved a problem, with both parties intact.  or so I thought.  I returned to check up on my Ghoul/tower residents, and I noticed something amiss. The former tower leader, was gone, and so were a few of the other human residents. Some investigating later, I found the bodies of a few of the previous Human occupants, shoved in a storage closet. I questioned the Ghoul leader, and he dismissed the murders as 'accidents' related to 'disagreements'.   I lost it. I slayed every single Ghoul in that tower, I felt betrayed. Had I not done the good thing? I made two groups coexist. In my quest for an ideal solution I did not see the underlying problem.   And now my charecter sits in an empty tower. Filled with neither Ghouls nor Humans, contemplating the error of my choice, dwelling on my unsastisfying rampage against the ghouls that betrayed me. All the while marvelling at the game design, and how it made clear moral choices murky.

Out of any company that could've gotten the rights to the Fallout franchise it had to be Bethesda, the company notorious for dumbing down the Scrolls series, Fallout was once an intricate RPG that focused on character progression, decision making that actually had an impact on the world around you, deep interaction with NPC's and using tactics to overcome tough disadvantages.  Fallout 3 is nothing more than an action game in an open world, with barely any RPG elements at all besides for upgrading your players stats everytime you level up, which have no consequence as to how your game plays out seeing as it's so damn easy in any case, as you basically role play as Superman which allows you to put little regard in thought when it comes to building your character.  The decision making, which is an extremely massive part in every true RPG's soul, has been narrowed down to 'Good guy/Bad guy' decisions rather than offering you multiple options, each which have a consequential impact minor or big that make you feel more involved with the world. The plot, another important aspect of RPG, is as generic and un-inspired as they come, a 12 year old could've written this.  In Fallout 3 there is NEVER any sense of danger, ever, you can traverse from one end of the map to the other with ease, unlike the older games in which travelling was a major risk and each encounter felt like it could be your last. I really hope they're using a better team for Fallout 4 because if it's anything like this dumbed down generic open world FPS it's going to stink, if you really want to play a modern Fallout, I'd suggest you play New Vegas, they attempt to fix most of the issues in this mess otherwise you're better off playing Fallout 1 and 2.

Fallout 3 is one of my all-time favourite games, and was one of the first games i got when i started getting serious about gaming back in 2008. The feeling of being in a destroyed neo-50's american world has a great affect on gameplay; to be surrounded by a futuristic twist on what was probably the peak of American culture while listening to tracks of American Swing and Jazz Blues while beating a Deathclaw to death after it surprise-attacked you and made you soil your pants is an experience that will only be found in the Fallout games.  The story of Fallout 3 is very reminiscent of the plots behind Fallout 1 and 2, and whilst i would say that i'd rather see a completely different story to the original games, there is far more story and content to make up for the main storyline which in my opinion wasn't anything new.  This game has allowed me to understand and enjoy an old genre of music that is found constantly played through the Galaxy News Radio station. I can't begin to tell you how many times i've listen to Bob Crosby and Cole Porter.  What this game does best and what i find Bethesda Game Studios to do best at in all their games is atmosphere and the feeling of being in the world that they are trying to portray. They did an extremely good job of capturing that post-Apocalyptic feel that aligns well with the classic games, but there are subtle differences because of the location and the different developers.  Combat is very fun, but not as responsive as some of the best shooters out there, but i'll give Bethesda credit as they are known for fantasy games where there is no such thing as fast fire-rate guns, since this is there first time at making an open world shooter RPG they did a good job at least. VATS is definitely the best part about combat, and the gore is super funny. The reaction i'd make to a super mutant's head exploding after a 32. caliber round through the skull is again one of the perks of playing this game.  There is a split of opinion between the new fans and the classic fans. My first Fallout experience was Fallout 3 but eventually i bought the older games and aced both of them, and i think all of them are great. I love this franchise and always will. I definitely recommend this game if you're new to the franchise, and then move onto New Vegas and then the classics.  Overall, i rate this game a 9.5/10. There is so much to do in this game, from taking in the lore, to the happy-go music, the rich culture and the endless gory fun, you will not go wrong by spending your money on this game.

Please don't look at the time I've allegedly spend playing this game, since Steam, for some reason, does not register it at all.   'Fallout 3' is one of those games, that I can recommend without any doubts. I know that there are fans of Fallout 1&2 out there, who do not like the changes within game mechanics, but I would say that it's perfectly normal - when something that we really enjoy change a lot, we usually react badly. I did not play any previous 'Fallout', so I judge this as a standalone game. And what a great game it is.   Pros: + music  + open world with tons of locations, secrets, references, memorable characters and pretty much everything else that you would like to see in the game like this + plot - some people say that it's the worse part of the game, but for me plot was good enough + player's stats that can unlock new dialogue options (not only charisma, but strength or perception), that actually make a difference (for example allows us to avoid fight) + perks are awesome. You can use your experience points to raise one of your stats or just add new skills (not only combat related. You can unlock perk that increase the gore effect, allows you to easily influence other gender or children, add new dialogue options and that's only the beginning) + pretty good morality system, that influence the way that some characters in the game treat us (and if potential companions will be interested in joining forces with us) + there are always at least two ways to solve each quest (and quite often more) + humor - dark and grotesque, it fits this game very well + moddable (it's easy and there are quite a lot 'Fallout 3' mods out there) + lore, atmosphere and atmosphere once again. Choosing your hair, mustache, perks, quests, dialogues, creatures - everything fit perfectly into the Fallout world.  Cons: - DLC are not interesting at all. Beside possibility of gaining 30 level, there's not much to them. You can't bring your companions on extra adventures. What is worse, they can be very challenging and sometimes you don't have a chance to properly prepare yourself. The best things that I have to say about Fallout 3 all have to do with how they handled the atmosphere, backstory and location. Setting FO3 in DC was a great choice, what better place to set a Fallout story? They really captured the Fallout feeling with this game but it's clear they put a different spin on it. It has more of a hopeful feeling instead of the darker, horror like sound that Mark Morgan brought to the first 2, which I liked a lot but I think I like Inon Zur's work better. Fallout 3 does a great job at fleshing out the world too, some of the best stories you'll see in this game are found in the computer terminal logs and random notes you'll find, they did a great job with those and clearly put a lot of work into them.    The main quest is overall hit or miss but will possibly leave you feeling frustrated if you don't have broken steel dlc. I didn't like it, I think the concept is good even though it's pretty clear they took it from Fallout Tactics, it could've been executed a lot better and it definiately felt forced. The DLC is one of my favorite things about this one, Point Lookout is one of my favorite locations in the series so far, the Pitt and Anchorage are also great. My biggest complaint about this game is how they copy pasted a few of the critical story moments from the first 2 games and shamelessly took credit for it from people who never played the first 2. A good example of this would be how you get exiled from vault 101 or how they had a settlement based around and inside a tanker.   Overall, it's a good game, I know it's controversial among some sections of the Fallout community and I was kind of on the Fallout 3 hate bandwagon for a while but I think there is a lot of things this game does right that makes it unique from the other entries. I think Bethesda can make a great Fallout game, they just need to put more emphasis on the main quest and lore next time.

Absolutely brilliant. If you're a fan of RPGs, or you're a fan of post-apocalyptic settings, then Fallout 3 is most likely for you. Set around 200 years after the Earth is devastated by nuclear war, you play the Vault Dweller, who has left Vault 101 in order to follow their father's footsteps and make sure he is still alive.  Of course, it's never quite that simple, and once you are out into the wide, open world, you are on your own. For a while at least. Fallout 3 Where do i begin... This game took the semi-popular fallout franchise and revolutionised it in a way that must have seemed genius at the time although now we find ideas like that common-place by making Third/First person.  For anyone who is new to the fallout universe, or just want a tad of backstory, here it is: Fallout 3 is based in the ruins of Washington DC which was destroyed in a war between America and China that ended with most of America turned into a nuclear wasteland. You have grown up in one of the many Vaults built by the government for what was thought to be protection against the war, but they where really built as a social experiment, with each vault being subjected to different experiments, from white noise to genetic mutations to never being allowed to open, all of which the inhabitants of these Vaults were unnaware of when they moved in.  Now to the game its self. Fallout has pulled of the wasteland feel so well, from the survival to the ruins to all the strange and just down right wrong enemys you'll face. It has a great soundtrack based around the 50s-60s era which adds a strangely happy tone to the mood. The graphics are nothing special, but take into consideration how old it is. The weapons system just adds to the wasteland feel, with having to find ammo in the wasteland, and having to fix your weapons if the get to worn out. The most iconic part of this game is the armour, i mean just look at the game art, already you see a set of impressive armour, which just makes people to want it more.  Alright lets wrap this up. Overall this game was groundbreaking when it came out, and to this day its still fun to return to the great DC ruins once more for another adventure, and isn't that what makes a game great? the ability to replay the game with the same enthusiasm as if you where playing it for your first time again. This game has shown me the greatest part of a nuclear Apocolypse, and that is... Adventure.  9.5/10  -=LevitatingBacon=-

Since Fallout 4 is nearing it's release date I'll release a review for Fallout 3. Now before I start I'll end the common debate most people have when they want to start playing the Fallout series... DO I PURCHASE FALLOUT NEW VEGAS OR FALLOUT 3? Well since I have both I'll write down the pros and the cons of both games so bear with me for now. Fallout 3 Pros + Very story rich, tells you about the Lone Wanderer and how he/she was born and raised. + Is a very beautiful game in my personal opinion. + Very nice radio that will keep you entertained while travelling the Washington wasteland. + Multiple endings so you can keep playing this game over and over. + THREE DOG AND DOGMEAT. + Very big atmosphere that's entirely yours to explore. + VATS is a wonderful gameplay mechanic that is introduced in Fallout 3. + Karma meter which makes you feel like you're an actual person instead of just a mindless killer. Fallout 3 Cons - No iron sight aiming. - Not optimized for Windows 7 or later. (This doesn't mean that it's unplayable on Windows 7 it's just that you have to modify the game files and that's really time consuming. Took me about 7 hours to fix Fallout 3 for my Windows 7 computer.) - Somewhat small level cap (20, but can be increased with the Broken-Steel DLC) - Very short main story line. - Companions AREN'T invincible. - Doesn't have an indicatior for when weapons are really worn thus making them more likely to jam. Now that I've talked a bit about Fallout 3 I'll talk about the pros and cons of Fallout: New Vegas Fallout: New Vegas Pros + Iron sight aiming. + VATS is a returning feature in Fallout: New Vegas. + Companions are invincible. + Hardcore mode is an option for all you hardcore fans out there. + Runs fine on Windows 7 and later (managed to run it on my terrible computer at a stable 60 FPS.) + A better radio than Fallout 3 (in my personal opinion.) + Weapon modification is an option. + REX. + You're in Las Vegas, what more do I need to say? + Some fun gambling to do in The Strip if that's your thing. + Increasing level cap if you have DLC installed. (Increases by 5 for each DLC, 30 is the base level cap.) + Very big and beautiful world, but not as big as Fallout 3. + The Kings. + No karma requirements to recruit companions. + Reputation for factions. Fallout: New Vegas - Tons of invisible walls over the Mojave Wasteland. - No back story AT ALL about our player character: The Courier. - Very limited story endings. - A lot of walking must be done unless you have found some places to fast travel to.  - TONS of bugs. - A.I isn't as good as in Fallout 3. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Now for the review of Fallout 3: You start off as a baby that is newly born. You then have a time skip to you as a toddler, and another to when you're 10, and 15. Finally when you're 18 the game really starts. This game is beautiful the moment you step out of Vault 101 and see the sunlight for the first time. It's not too far into the game when you meet Dogmeat, a fan favourite companion loved by all. During this time you are already free to do as you please and explore the Washington wastelands. This game is entirely based by your actions so it's amazing that you get to choose how the game will end. Will you be a villian feared all across the wasteland? Or will you be the guardian angel of the wasteland? If you want to find out... BUY THIS GAME! (Ps. took me about an hour to write, enjoy)

Fallout 3. This is a game that will, most of the time, suck you in with its amazing atmosphere and environments. I say most of the time because, just like the Steam notice says there, it's not optimized for Windows 7. Now I have Windows 7, and I fully played through all the content in this game, and what I believe they're trying to say with that is that this game has a bunch of performance issues. Fallout 3 loves to crash. A lot. As in, it made me press the quicksave button all the time so I'd make sure I wouldn't lose as much progressas I potentially could. However, I did play through everything, and I loved it. In fact, this is the second time that I've played through everything in Fallout 3. I just love the game so much that even the regular crash couldn't stop me.  The very first part of the game is so well done, very immersive and eases you into the game proper nicely. Don't expect amazing shooting mechanics, while it does have FPS mechanics (you'll never used third person camera because of how bad it is for combat) you don't play it for the shooting. You play it instead for the RPG elements, the storytelling, and the impeccable atmosphere the Wasteland offers you. It's grim, it's gory, it's gritty, it is a complete hellhole on a destroyed post-apocalyptic Washington D.C. Many of the landmarks that characterize D.C in the real world are very well replicated here in its ruined and wrecked glory.   The Fallout universe itself is a joy to be in, with its 50's/futuristic quirks, power armors, aliens, big guns that really go BOOM, and freaky mutations. The game did give me quite a few jumpscares when I was caught unawares by some of the wildlife. The V.A.T.S system is awesome as you pick your favorite body part and shoot, complete with guts and gore flying everywhere as your enemies die. Good stuff.  The inevitable question when it comes to this game is: 'Is it better than New Vegas or is it the other way around?' I would say that even though I slightly prefer New Vegas, both are worth playing anyway because it shows both Bethesda and Obsidian's strong (and weak) points. And both are good games in their own right.  Bethesda made Fallout 3. And what makes Bethesda great are both its sidequests (which are always more interesting than the main story itself) and its attention to detail in its environments. They love to litter the landscape with information, each containing a small story or information explaining why that skeleton's standing in that bathroom, for example. And sometimes it doesn't, all it shows you, all it needs, is the scenery itself that tells the story for you. This makes exploration really engaging and fun because things rarely feel they're copypasted (except the subway tunnels but there's only so much you can do to make a ruined subway tunnel stand out, though some do stand out anyway).  The quests themselves have multiple solutions and most of the time offer choice, like a good RPG should, and trust me, you can do some extreme stuff in these which will literally change the landscape, but then again, these choices and this engaging writing are severely lacking in the main quest itself, which is clichéd and ultimately really linear.   I prefer Obsidian's writing overall, so New Vegas wins out on Fallout 3 for me there. Fallout 3 though, like any good sandbox RPG should do, which New Vegas does not, is allow you to keep playing after the actual ending. In NV's defense though, there are so many endings that it would be hell to program into, but still, it's something worth keeping an eye out for.  Fallout 3's the oldest game of the two, so it will, gameplay-wise, lack a few features NV adds in later on.  Like any modern Bethesda RPG, Fallout 3 adds much needed mod support which makes the PC version by far the best, allowing you to fix many of its faults, and become an even better experience than it already is. Though I'd recommend just sticking to performance mods the first time around, as some of these mods can change the game dramatically.  The DLC for the game itself is a bit hit and miss in my opinion. DLCs like Broken Steel which let you keep playing the game after its conclusion, or Point Lookout and The Pitt, which add areas of their own with stuff to do are great, but Anchorage and Zeta, though unique, don't add to the game all that much, and you wouldn't feel like something's missing if these never came out.  All in all, I totally recommend this game, lots of RPG goodness and with mod support, can have you keep coming for more.

If you never played a Fallout game before, try the original Fallout before picking this up. Whether you enjoyed the first or not, and whether you tried the second as well, then see how long you can last playing this mess of a game.   I'll admit, when I first picked it up, I enjoyed it immeadiately, and binged it for hours. It is quite a bit of fun, if not stupid fun. As you play on, you begin to realize how loosely the story and world of the game is held together. The plot is nonsensical, the characters are cliche as hell, there are strictly two sides (black and white of course) to the story, the weapons are uninspired and bland, and they, to say it in a juvenile fashion, feel like sticks with ♥♥♥♥ on the ends of them. Not to mention the game's enviornment is spotty and dull. That green tint can get ♥♥♥♥ing old quick, and oftentimes, you will have no idea where you are until you take a gander at the map. It's like Bethesdashit just made a basic desert world on a piece of paper, tacked it to the wall, and threw a ♥♥♥♥-ton of darts at it to denote where they would put places, events, towns, and so-on. No rhyme or reason as to where anything is.     This game also suffers from the same problem that a lot of Bethesdacrap games have, such as very poorly made animations, weapons that feel like cardboard sticks or airsoft guns, ugly as sin character models, a strong lack of voice actors to compensate for the vast amount of 'unique' characters in the game, no vareity in clothing, and broke leveling mechanics. Di I say the story makes no sense when you look at the big picture? It's as if a pre-teen fanfic writer smoked some pot and wanted to make a Fallout story.    Despite these shortcomings, I rate the game a 4/10 for having a small amount of replayability, a vision that shines through the cracks of caked-on ♥♥♥♥, and a very nostalgic and memorable soundtrack (not the terrible and generic OST created for the game, I'm talking about anything that plays on Galaxy News Radio, and not Three-dog's annoying vocal-chord vibrations he calls a voice).    Once you trudge through the wasteland, play every DLC (if you didn't max out your character's level by the end of the game) minus Mothership Zeta for something different, and then high-tail your ♥♥♥ to the Mojave in Fallout New Vegas, which in my opnion, is the true Fallout 3. Do NOT skip this game if you intend to jump into New Vegas! If you play this first, you will enjoy it a tad, and it will allow you to enjoy New Vegas a lot more due to the problems it fixes and the soul it has to offer. If you play New Vegas first, you will not enjoy Fallout 3 at all, making both games seem kind of dull and leaving a bad taste in your mouth. Just pray that Bethesdick collaborates with the guys behind New Vegas on the next Fallout.

Due to the fact that I played Fallout 3 after New Vegas and Skyrim, I was really afraid of what I would experience in the game that's 7 years old and commonly hated in the Fallout fandom. As with all other games, I decided to play it COMPLETELY unmodded, in order to experience the very game Bethesda wanted us to play.  I played New Vegas and simply loved it. Also, I played Skyrim and even today I consider it to be the best game I have ever played. Hyping myself for Fallout's 4th installment, I decided to buy Fallout 3 and ultimately decided whether it's so bad as many people say. Surprise, surprise - it's not!   The beginning is very slow-paced, but it gives a nice touch to the whole story. But right after entering Megaton - boy, was I impressed. That was the very moment when I felt the 'Bethesda spirit', because of which I love their games so much. Interesting backstory of the location, quite nice backstories of each character in the 'city', a lot of interesting loot, nice dialogues and the big introduction to the essence of the game - BE GOOD OR BE BAD.  The morality/consequence system in the game is based on extremities - there are just a few moments when you can stay neutral with your decision. Therefore, most time you decide whether you want to be good or bad. However, sometimes your seemingly good/bad choices can result in the opposite of your intention - that is why a player has to THINK while deciding - it pays off and it's really cool.  Due to the common belief that F:NV is a better game than F3, I'd like to contribute a few words to the discussion. As a whole, I consider F:NV to be the better one, but my F3 playthrough was twice longer than any on my F:NV playthroughs. Draw some conclusions. Also, Washington in F3 seems to be much more affected by the atomic explosions than Las Vegas in F:NV. The whole world of F3 seems also to be more miserable and hopeless in contrary to the one of F:NV, which seemingly make it more suitable to the postapocalyptic vision, but I guess it's a matter of taste - personally, I still like more the atmosphere of New Vegas, but I completely understand why some people prefer the one from Fallout 3.   The gameplay is rewarding and satisfying - every kill, succesful attempt of persuasion/lockpick/etc. results in earned exp, which just HAS to make you feel good - and it does. You can have your own home that you can upgrade with some Fallout lore technology, you can capture people to make them slaves, you can hunt slavers, you can help or kill almost any person that has his/her's own personality and habits. Oh, btw - habits. I love the habit system, as it makes the world feel ALIVE, and the immersion is the first thing that I'm looking for in RPG games. NPCs have their break-times, eat breakfast/dinner, sleep and have random conversations between each other. So, if you suffer lack of funds, why not steal from the cash register of some folk? You walk into the shop, but he observes your every move. Solution? Just break into the shop during the night time - he will be sleeping, so as long as you maintain to be silent, you're good to go. AWESOME.  Now, some bad things. Unlike developers wanted me to, I completed all of the available DLCs BEFORE ending the main story. As for the DLCs - they are mediocre at their least. Some of them are even worse. Somehow, I regret my decision to play them instead of discovering the locations from the main map. Most of the DLCs are linear ('Point Lookout' is the only exception) and - let's face it - just boring. Playing them wasn't a very good idea also because of one more reason - with little more than half of the game's locations discovered, I hit the 30lvl cap and the game became a dull chore - the character progression just stopped - no more perks, no more skills. Therefore, I was forced to install a mod which allowed me to raise the level cap. After 62hrs of gameplay, I raised almost all of my skills to 100 and raised all of my S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stats to 9/10. I know that there are some mods that actually fix this problem, but I wanted to play the game itself, not its modded counterpart. Now, the only thing left is to discover the rest of the locations (20-30, maybe) and to finish the Broken Steel DLC (which is available only after finishing the main questline). Now, I probably need a short break before I complete the game in 100%.  Also, the optimisation! It's... bad. Skyrim runs much more fluently on my laptop, and it's a game that is 3 years younger. And much bigger. And prettier. At the very start, the game was unplayable with its constant freezes and crashes. This solution fixed it for me, both on my desktop PC (i5, GTX 970) and laptop (i7, GT650M SLI):  'Open up the fallout.ini file in: My Documents\My Games\Fallout3  Find the line:  bUseThreadedAI=0  change it to:  bUseThreadedAI=1  Add another line after it and insert:  iNumHWThreads=2  This will limit the game to 2 cores and prevent the engine bug from causing the game to freeze.'  Hope that you find it helpful!  With all of its advantages and disadvantages, Fallout 3 is still a great action RPG.  [EDIT]: I've just finished the 'Broken Steel' DLC (same as the rest, linear and mediocre). The main good thing about it is that it's short. I visited couple more locations and lost interest in this title. Still, overall it's a great game that provides many hours of satisfactory and rewarding gameplay.

Why Fallout 3 is better than New Vegas...  Opening: What could be a better start to an RPG than being born? New Vegas uses a tired cliche about being shot in the head and asks the players to suspend their disbelief by telling them, like many RPGs before them, that they have lost part of their memory. With Fallout 3, there is no need for that suspension of disbelief, you know your history, you remember being born, you remember the big events of your childhood.  Story: Your father leaves under mysterious circumstances and doesn't realize the danger this puts you in so you have to effect your own escape from your vault. Once you are out, are you going to track down the father who just up and left you without a word? Will you realize that he has a way to purify the water for everyone in the D.C area? Will you help him or stand in his way? These are all big questions you have to answer in Fallout 3. In New Vegas you are asked to decide between competing political factions as to who gets control of the Hoover dam.  Locations: Sure, New Vegas has real cities that you can go and visit. You can go find Primm and see the roller coaster, you can find goodsprings and see the saloon, but Fallout 3 has one city built around an unexploded nuke, one city built on an abandoned aircraft carrier, and an underground city populated only by children.  The only place where New Vegas is better is the DLC Dead Money and Old World Blues otherwise, Fallout 3 wins hands down.

Much can be said about Fallout 3, whether you're trying to take down the Enclave and there villainous ways or wondering through the Wasteland you will always find excitment and adventure wherever you go.  Seven years later it still has the same effect of mystery fear and excitment all mixed into one like a fruit cake of life.  However even after Seven years it still stands a testiment of time, to be able to personally choose your fate as you went about your buisness was revolutionary; The vast emptiness of the Wasteland made it feel like a harsh enviroment to be in both physically and mentally. Watching people scrouging through bins for food and drinking iradiated water does make you think to yourself if society as we know it today would even be able to survive in such conditions without Wifi, hair dryers and sitting on the sofa watching the tele all afternoon.  With the game taking place in the year 2277, two hundred years after the appocolypse, the hero or villain of Vault 101 steps out and embraces the harsh relality that is life on the outside.   The combat in itself was fresh and brand new to the world that it overtook everything in the market, especially with the V.A.T.S System machanic which allowed the player to freeze time and zoom in on specific parts of the enemies body and allow you to pick shots off making you feel like a total god, which is a fantastic feeling especially when you're sniping someone with the aid of V.A.T.S and you see their head explode... But I digress...  Anyway Fallout 3 has got to be rated one of the best RPG games in existence; yes it has flaws that needed to be ajusted, but the overall feel and atmospher of the game made it as though you were in a trance that systimatcially guilt tripped you into playing it by luling you into a false sense of secruty to the point where the game wispers in your ear whilst you slept, 'It's okay if you don't want to play me, I understand, I will wait for you no matter how long it takes.'  And then you wake up in a cold sweat thinking to yourself, 'Oh bugger it I forgot to explore this part of the Wasteland.'  Furthermore for a game to make me think this surely it has to be rated as one of the creepiest and or one of the best to be abe to have such an impact on the gaming community. Yes it is old but it will still hold onto us like a child holding onto its mother after they've just had their lollypop taken from them, yes it can be annoying but there is an adorablness to it as it may get old but it will never be forgotten.

For starters, let's say I didn't hate playing FO3. I've beaten it few times, did the majority of quests and even played all the DLC's. I even had fun doing that. Do I recommend playing it? Maybe. Is it a terrible game? No. There, I said it. Moving on.   Here's my main gripe: FO3 is what happens when you take a fantastically written post-apocalyptic game series and hand the rights over to a company whose writers appear to be 12-year-olds.  Imagine a world where every city, every store and every household is an entity separate from the surrounding world. Nothing has an effect on anything else. There's a town a miles down the road with a problem with Raiders? Yeah, that doesn't really affect this storekeeper couple. Heaps of radscorpions make life a living hell for a bunch of settlers living in a run-down village? Yeah, that has no bearing on this other community a stone's throw away, their only problem pertains to fixing their fertility robot. Oh, and getting their hands on a vacuum tube located 20 miles away because reasons.  When you have dozens of locations with seemingly no connection to one another or the main plot, you end up with a huge sandbox that barely resembles the intricate interconnected plots of the first two games. That's Fallout 3's setting in a nutshell. Real world doesn't work like that. If your counter-argument is 'this is a game, not the real world lol' you're completely missing the point. Fallout 1 and 2 came out years before FO3 and yet they still managed to accomplish a sense of reality - albeit a very far-fetched and sometimes tongue-in-cheek one.  Take Fallout 2, where you have a complicated, interconnected political web between New Reno, Redding, Vault City and NCR. Take Fallout: New Vegas where everything rotates around the ongoing conflict between NCR and Caesar's Legion. Everyone has a say in this, everybody is affected. Your choices affect the outcome and the ongoing power structure. That's how you write a game. And that's where FO3 falls flat on its face.  The main plot is bland. I felt like I had no reason to follow the PC's dad. Instead I ran around, doing quests here and there, fetching this and killing that, getting little satisfaction from the caps and experience I accumulated. It wasn't really rewarding. None of it. Just a mindless, momentary distraction on the road to the grave.  Oh, and the metro tunnels suck.

Yes I recommend this game. It is a nice FPS Lite RPG in the Oblivion engine. Now, It does not have the character of the prior 2 fallout titles. Those games have writing full of wit, sarchasm, heart and soul, and the writing in this game feels incredibly sterile comparatively. When you accomplished a task in those games, it actually felt like you accomplished something. Yes that is in part due to the time spent in menus, running thru areas, etc. However, the uneasy feeling you get playing those games is commesurate with the whole experience. Desolate wasteland, sparsely populated, with more bad than good left. Quests could be completed in a multitude of ways, and I don't just mean good and bad. The Black Isle (Now inexile and obsidian) guys did some great stuff.  For us older Fallout fans, the comparison is necssary. While this game suffers from the sterility of Bethesda writing, (lets face it..they design great environments and litter them with bland npcs and quests..quantity over quality), they still manage to capture a retro 50s vibe and many nods to fallout. For me, the DC wastes were a plus as I am a fan of American history (not the sanitized version they teach kids either). The game looked great for 2008, and played ok. It is extremely dumbed down for an rpg of Fallout's lineage, but that is why it is a good game. As much as it pains me to say this, the old fallouts didn't age well, and even back 17 or 18 years ago, were very obtuse. Yes, the way rpgs should be. While us RPG fans loved it, they were not as marketable. Bethesda wanted to make a game many would buy. The scores the game got prove this. The reason Bethesda even owns the IP is because the CRPGS were not doing well. Graphics and flash got in the way. Now that we are used to the 'next gen grapics', as they've been around roughly a decade, the desire for gameplay and substance over flash is returning. This is evidenced by the killing D:OS and WL2 made.   The formula in this game is fun and addicting. I am not as harsh on it as other members of the fallout famdom. If this was just an original IP, it wouldn't get that hate. Many fans felt as if Bethesda 'ruined' their IP with zero chamce of redemption. Until they let Obsidian make New Vegas..  If you want a fun Lite RPG (no complex char design, choices don't mean that much, followers suck, too easy etc), FPS style with a cool retro vibe, buy it. It's cheap now. Fans of the OG fallouts, I am sure you already have an opinion lol. I never had expectations of it being like the other games, as I thought the isometric CRPG was dead (it's not! :) ). Therefore, I enjoyed my time with this game, and all the expansions, for what it is. If I didn't have the meterstick of games designed by what I consider the Beatles of the CRPG, this game would be a lot better for me. Oh, obviously I didn't play this version on steam much. All my hours were on 360. I would replay it, but why when I have 1, 2, and NV to replay, along with a dozen or more other great rpgs and the incoming crop of new ones.

What an incredible game.  My first Fallout experience was with New Vegas on the Xbox 360. I liked it but I felt the story fell a little short and got quickly boring as the Mojave desert is about as interesting as it sounds. With the reveal of Fallout 4 however, I wanted to give it another shot but with Fallout 3 instead of New Vegas. And wow, I have never been so blown away...  First of all, the story is amazing. A long intro (one that took me about an hour to get out of the vault and start exploring) but one hell of a setup for a story. The storyline does, however, seem a little short but the expansive wasteland led me to new areas to explore, new towns and new interesting NPCs with unique pre-war backstories. This meant it took me an excessive amount of time to actually get to the places involving the story missions, and so inflating my game time and enjoyment.  Of course the graphics are dated but that does not mean the gameplay is. Bethesda focused on the gameplay overall and wiped the floor with some of today's 'all graphics, no gameplay' titles.   Several unique mechanics are seen in this game, like the VATs system, which is Bethesda's answer to keeping the real-time strategy element from the first game and other's like Fallout: Tactics while implementing first person elements, which were new to the franchise at the time. Other mechanics like the S.P.E.C.I.A.L skills allow you to specify what your character is best at, whether he is strong but stupid, or intelligent but prone to injury. This links to the character's persuasiveness against NPCs. For example, a character with high intelligence would be able to get through to a scientist NPC more than he/she would with a soldier NPC. These mechanics give such incredible role-playing gameplay that lead to Bethesda being renowned artists of the genre, with other titles like Oblivion and Skyrim under their belt.  In conclusion, Fallout 3 is now one of, if not my favourite RPG game out there, and for good reason.

Tl;dr 'Skyrim with guns' (Skyrim uses almost exactly the same engine)  I don't have many hours logged because I launch it through the mod manager, not steam.  I've also logged about 1000+ hours on the other 3 times I've bought this game on other platforms, or rebuying it because it broke or got stolen.  I would rate this game as the second-best game of all time (behind Pokemon Emerald, in case you're curious.) I could describe this game for hours on end and it wouldn't do it justice at all. You need to experience it for yourself. And it's absolutely essential that you get the GOTY edition.  This game has thousands of hours of replay value if you know what you're doing. The first time I played this game, I only did the main quest, and finished the game in about 24 gameplay hours (if you don't have the DLC, you can't keep playing after you beat the main quest.) I don't recommend playing this way. Then I made a second character (there are virtually unlimited save slots, even on console), and discovered all of the sidequests, DLC, the radio (IMO the best part about the game and the biggest difference between Fallout 3 and New Vegas), and started to get totally obsessed. At this point I have a profile that is level 30 (highest level with DLC) with max of all skills and SPECIAL (I love the leveling system in this game, btw) in under 48 gameplay hours, because I've memorized most of the game at this point. So you'd think I'd be bored of the game, right? Wrong. Play the game until you get tired of it, and then get into the MODS. Easily doubles gameplay hours.  You can really get into the roleplaying if you want. It's surprisingly immersive. If immersion isn't your thing, there are several things in the game that bring you back to earth. For example, your father is voiced by Liam Neeson. I constantly break RP and refer to him as Liam Neeson.  I don't have to tell you how to play the game, since you can do whatever you want, really. There are several 'classes' that I make my characters into: Big guns tank, small guns or energy weapons (frail but deadly), sneak assassins (obscenely overpowered if you do Operation Anchorage DLC), unarmed tank, melee weapons specialist, etc. If you level your character correctly you can be all of them and carry an arsenal with you. Do whatever you want and treat your first character as a throw-away, then get serious with your second or third character.   The character creation was revolutionary for its time, but it's fallen behind more modern ones. I almost always make my character female, because there's a perk at level 2 that gives you a 10% damage bonus to the opposite gender, and most of the people you'll be killing are male.  10/10 would purchase a fifth time.

Red Dead Redemption is a Western epic, set at the turn of the 20th century when the lawless and chaotic badlands began to give way to the expanding reach of government and the spread of the Industrial Age. A follow up to the 2004 hit Red Dead Revolver, this game tells the story of former outlaw John Marston, taking players on a great adventure across the American frontier.  Red Dead Redemption features an open-world environment for players to explore, including frontier towns, rolling prairies teaming with wildlife, and perilous mountain passes - each packed with an endless flow of varied distractions. Along the way, players will experience the heat of gunfights and battles, meet a host of unique characters, struggle against the harshness of one of the world’s last remaining wildernesses, and ultimately pick their own precarious path through an epic story about the death of the Wild West and the gunslingers that inhabited it.

Expansive, awesome and beautiful. Fallout 3 is what RPGs aspire to.   Featuring a long absence from the 90s classics Fallout 1 and 2, Bethesda Softworks brings back Fallout for a new generation. Awaking in an apocalyptic nightmare, your own hope to survive in this new world is to explore, upgrade and befriend or back-stab as many people as you can.  Fallout 3 is a gorgeously realised game not only in its visuals, but the narrative, its atmosphere and the unremarkable but noticable human touches throughout.  Fallout 3 is one to recommend, albeit you can find yourself wandering through a carbon copy of the same underground tunnel or factory at times, but that's nothing to greatly disservice such a great experience.

TL;DR: No, I don't recommend buying it but it's somewhat nice to play for one time. And now to the point. +1. I kind of liked the Wasteland this game provides. It doesn't feel like Wasteland from classic games, but it definitely has something appealing in it's looks. +2. Somewhat liked the main story, that   retro simulation   looks pretty good, even has   a little puzzle.    +3. Repair system. Once again, it is 'kind of' great, allows you to repair stuff -> thus keeping your inventory clean, get some more damage for your gun or 'armor' aka 'damage protection' for your armor or helmet. -1. Totally stupid characters, like that guy Tenpenny. Remember how he   hires some mercs to kill you?  . Why does he even have such relations to do so? Isn't he like all the 'WOO, YOU'RE NOT GOOD ENOUGH'? -2. Absolutely stupid DLC. Somewhat liked (yeah, i won't stop from using 'kind of' and 'somewhat' in this review) liked The Pitt, but the rest.. O: Anchorage is the worst CoD clone ever made. CoD made out of kind-of-open-world-rpg. 'Nice' idea. Mothership Zeta got me so bored that I decided not to finish other DLC's. Had a hope for Broken Steel, was planning to do it last, but screw that, i've got enough. -3. 'Open world'. All the locations are totally unnecessary, uncreative and stuff. When you reach the border of 'open world' game just says 'You can't go there, please turn back'. Literally. Remember how 'non-open-world' game called 'Borderlands 2' did? It has some guns which are exterminating you if you don't turn back. EVEN THAT is better than what Fallout 3 does. -4. 'RPG'. Fallout 3 is not an RPG. You don't have to do trading at all, you can get through all the game by looting stuff. That kind of looks nice, right? Guess what - it's not. Just because you have so limited amount of 'skills' to choose from and 'Barter' is one of them. To get successful you'll only need Speech, Lockpicking and Science. Everything else is optional as hell. +4. Surprisingly, Fallout 3 allows you to do stuff different ways. Kill someone or not, negotiate or threaten.  So overall I regret there's no 'neutral' reviews, but looking back to my experience - I'd say  I don't recommend this game  to any RPG and/or Fallout fans. And by 'Fallout fans' I mean people who played Fallout 1/2 when they were a cutting-edge-just-released-wow-nice-graphics games, not the people who started being Fallout fans in Fallout3+ era. No offense intended.

I'll start off by saying that, like many other reviewers here, I LOVE this game. I've spent at least 200 hours on my old console and simply could not stop playing. The Fallout universe is one of the most fascinating and fun places you'll ever visit in your gaming experience. The game itself deserves no less than a 10/10, bugs aside.  This, however, is not a recommendation of the game. I'm urging any PC gamer, Fallout fan or otherwise, to NOT buy this game as it stands. If your OS is anything newer than Windows 7, you won't be able to run this game. Period. The store page warns that it's 'not optimized' for anything Windows 7 or beyond, which is a bold understatement. Instead, it should warn that it is simply unplayable on newer OSs.  There are numerous fixes floating around the modding community or through other programs and some youtube tutorials can help you get it up and running relatively quickly, but this is still an unnecessarily annoying issue.  [See EDIT] Recently, a Limited Edition PC Fallout Anthology has been announced and put up for pre-order in the wake of the Fallout 4 hype (which I snapped up as soon as I could, of course), so I'm hoping that Bethesda will have a compatibility patch in time for its release, which would only seem sensible if they're selling it in 2015. If not, it would be a huge insult to the fans of this great franchise.  I'll revisit this review when I get my Anthology and hopefully have better news, but until then, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ON PC.  TL;DR: The game is ****ing fantastic, but unplayable on PC. Buy New Vegas instead or wait for Fallout 4.  EDIT: The release of the anthology sadly saw no compatability update. Such a shame. It was still worth it for the collector's case and the great older Interplay games, but it still feels like a bit of a cheap shot that Bethesda would sell something exclusive to PC that isn't playable on any recent PCs. To be quite honest, I'm insulted. Apparently, it doesn't take long with mods to get the game running, meaning that the inclusion of a simple update to fix the issue is well within the realm of capability for Bethesda. Sure, some other simple mods fix some of the other numerous bugs, but the game is almost 8 years old so I can let them slide. We can't expect them to fully support a fix for every bug after so long. But one would think that a game-breaking issue would be addressed before the inclusion of the game in a recently released edition. I'm disappointed, Bethesda. *End rant.*

A fantastic open world RPG from the makers of fantastic open world RPG's.  Fallout is a post-nuclear war role playing game set in the vast universe of.. Washington D.C. America being America, they knew people wanted to kill them so they built many many underground shelters called Vaults, which would house people when the bombs fells, so they didn't die or mutate or any of that nasty stuff.  You've spent 18-19 years in Vault 101, and due to your SPOILER deciding to SPOILER SPOILER, you SPOILER. Crazy right!? You get a decent amount of customization of your character - including their ethnicity, facial features and hair - as well as a few basic traits that determine your starting strengths and weaknesses. The introduction isn't annoyingly long (not bad at all if you love making new characters), but isn't unfairly short (teaches you all of the simple mechanics pretty sharpish) and shortly after that is over, you're out of that Vault and staring over the intimidating nuclear wasteland. As I said before, this universe is vast and you are never tied down to one location (except the introduction, and the majority of the downloadable content packs). Similar to Fable and KOTOR, Fallout 3 uses a karma feature. When you're a ♥♥♥♥, you will scare and intimidate some people, making them act differently towards you. On the flip side, when you're a goodie people will like you (unless they themselves are a ♥♥♥♥) and act differently towards you. Either side opens up different skill options when you level up, so there are advantages to both.  I could keep going on and on, but a lot of this stuff is worth exploring for yourself. A few friends have told me they don't like the combat, or the trait system, others have told me they can't get enough of the game. I'd have to suggest finding some gameplay videos.  Aaaaaaand that's me out.

Finally got one of my all-time favorite games to run on Windows7x64:  - update the game with patch: 1.7 - turn off anti-aliasing - running the game on 1 processor, rather than all 4 - compatibilty mode: WindowsXP + SP3 - edit .ini file: bUseThreadedAI=1 then added this line: iNumHWThreads=2 - turned off screen-saver  game now runs without crashing...at least so far.

THIS REVIEW IS FROM THE PS3 Version of FALLOUT 3 including PC With Mods. BUT MOSLY THE PS3 VERSION Fallout 3 Was my first fallout game and introduction into the universe of Fallout and being better than oblivion and skyrim in my opinion.   But. is it a fun game? Well yes and a bit of no but mostly yes. Fallout 3 throws you in to ruined and long gone united states of America in the D.C Ruins also known as Capital wasteland. Emerged from your safe underground shelters known as Vaults. after many years the wasteland became a much harsher place to live in. such danger like bloodthirsty raiders. Mutants created from the radiation from the nuclear bombs. and mostly most feared beast in the wastes, the Deathclaws. (but not really)  After being raised in your vault. your father left the vault door open only to purse his dream for the wasteland. and only to escape the corrupt vault overseer and the vault security force to find your father in the cruel and harsh wasteland and to be togther again (yes thats the story in a nutshell)  But now to Gameplay This is an FPS RPG Game. Well if you shoot things you get XP. Level up and get a Perk. Set your skills to max your pretty much a Jack of all trades (with some expections).  Shooting things like raiders and radscorpions is kind of a hit and miss (Thanks to Ghoul reavers and Albino Radscorpions and Overlords) but you got this mechanic known as VATS. Pretty much a cheat as your in VATS Mode your pretty much invincible for a while with a slow cutscene of you shooting the raider in the eye and being unskipable and slow.  I don't use VATS Alot unlike in New vegas as an Unarmed Player given with Special VATS Attacks. I mostly use VATS As my enemy detector and my finisher move. but i mostly play real time combat without VATS.  You got your Small guns (SMGs, Pistols, Rifles and shotgusn) Big guns like the Flamer and the minigun and then the Energy weapons (Laser rifles, Plasma rifles and then the Gauss rifle)  You also got melee weapons too including unarmed but don't forget Michael bay Explosives  but it lacks a large Weapon rooster from FO2 and a bit from FO:Tactics (The FO1 Plasma Rifle made its way in Vegas As the Plasma Caster including the Plasma Pistol as the Plasma Defender) But the Unique versions of each weapon make up for it as such as a laser rifle shotgun combination being my favorite  but your here exploration then this game is for you! lots of loot and treasures to be found! going to a deathclaw infested place is rewarding giving you uniques but be sure to bring lots frag mines with you or atleast a dart gun and a sniper rifle.  Some quests including the main quest and the dlcs are a hit and miss. As such the vampire attacking a small town in a highway being my least favorite. (yes litterly vampires) Fallout is known for good and evil and very very evil and heartwarming tearjerking good decisions but i mostly play as a neutral karma mercenary  who stays in the middle in the see-saw listening to his shoulder angels like from that movie and cartoon. I Mean that lady in a house who accuses you for working for someguy named moriarty i mean oh my gosh what im i supposed to say if im talking like a jerk which is out of place for my character and no option to say *Nevermind im out of here -leave* rather than going the good thing or just killing her for evil lulz  Characters are good and mixed. Three dog being the likeable and talking about you (for some reason for one person unlike the tale of the vault dweller or the choosen one) Moria being cheerful and okay. Some characters being evil and make you want to punch them with your power fist. but you can't kill one of these guys except Three dog and Moria being killable.  The Main story characters and Rivet city are infamous for this i mean you can melt anyone to goo unlike in FO1&2 and Tactics Heck even in New Vegas. Look at Skyrims NPCs You can't kill one of these guys for some silly quest runing away from guards. Thats not right. i would rather go for the wild card path in New Vegas instead.  Theres a Karma system in this game. i mostly play Neutral Karama just give free water to some water beggars and make your decision for the more rewarding in a quest. But i don't play as a total jerk as i play as a mercenary looking for caps.  What is missing is the Traits and the Reputation system but that returned in New vegas and i hope it does in Fallout 4 along with low intelligence dialouge which is unlikely since i loved that in FO1 And 2.  Fallout 3 is a fun game to explore around like saving that kid from fire breathing ants. and shooting slavers in paradise falls freeing the kids and shooting the slaver leader and then shooting some scavengers and wastelands for evil lulz.  but it has it's flaws around in circules. the game gets easy even in normal settings and playing very hard turns some of the enemys into bullet sponges from my chinese assault rifle and even its unique counter part. Fallout 3 is a game full of surprises and suspense, backed up with an interesting story and addictive gameplay, it's a no brainer for anyone who is a fan of open world, story driven RPGs. I've put thousands of hours into this game on my Xbox (before I stopped being a filthy console peasant), and a few hundred on my PC (Using a custom launcher that for some reason didn't add play time to steam), and not a single minute was wasted.   The game follows the main protagonist, a vault dweller, whose father had committed the cardinal sin of leaving the vault to venture into the irradiated nuclear wasteland for an unknown purpose. The vault dweller, shunned by the other members of the vault and at risk of being killed as punishment for his/her father's crime, is forced to flee after their father into the harsh and unforgiving 'Capital Wasteland' to search for answers. The player is free to adventure across the vast wasteland surrounding post apocalyptic Washington DC, meeting slavers, bandits, mutated creatures and other survivors. There are countless settlements, derelict buildings, caves, underground train networks etc to explore, each containing their own piece of back story and perils, ranging from a renovated tower full of 'privileged' people who live above a network of ghouls who want nothing more than to get in, to the withered remains of the white house or the DC monument.  Following the main questline is recommended but not essential, and there are hundreds of side quests to follow, unique items to collect and moral dilemmas at every turn (such as whether to detonate a nuclear bomb killing an entire town of people for cash or not). If you've seen the recent announcement of Fallout 4 and wasn't sure if spending £49.99 on the pre order is a good idea, buy this game and put some time into it. It's made by Bethesda, a company renowned for the Elder Scrolls series of games, so if you are a fan of those, chances are, you'll be a fan of this!

When I first played Fallout 3 on PC it would regulary freeze mid-game with the ambient noises and soundtrack still active. I searched forums for a solution to this problem and came across this; it was very effective as the game ceased to freeze abruptly.   Go to your folder containing your FALLOUT.INI, FalloutPrefs and RendererInfo.txt files. Open FALLOUT.INI file and either add or modify the following lines:  bUseThreadedAI to 1 iNumHWThreads=2   Save and close.  This worked for me and I hope it works for you but I cannot guarantee it's the ultimate fix for the problem.

The Elder Scrolls 4.5 : Capital Wasteland is a good game. Fallout 3 is a terrible game. If this sounds like ramblings of a lunatic, well... you're not far off, but I'll attempt to clarify.  As a spiritual successor to installments 1 and 2 of the series, this game fails miserably. Apart from a very vague feeling that all this is kinda like fallout, there isn't much else here to satisfy the cravings of a fan of the original games. Move along.  However, this is still a solid (and typical) bethesda product, with its flaws and strengths. More or less everything about this game is the way it is in other installments in the elder scrolls series, with a few timid attempts to implement original fallouts' features (no more about that, though, since this is supposed the part where I actually complement the game). Yes, all the things you've had in morrowind and oblivion are here: a pretty short main quest line, which is hardly the poing anyway, lots of space for exploration, a decent number of side quests, some of which come with moral choices.  The game does deviate, understandably so, from TES leveling system, once again attempting to emulate the original, where you get to spend points on skills and perks once you've gathered enough experience points to level up.  To summarize, I would put it this way: it is a good game, it's just not a fallout game.

Your kids are going to love this game.  You hold weapons like an ego shooter, but the shooting and combat animation mechanics are broken because enemies will always move straight towards you. The person who thought that instead using VATS constantly in the game would be 'fun' should be fired. Especially if you take a companion with you, battles become laughably unrealistic.  The wasteland is a hostile, empty and large area. nothing more nothing less. and the little that there is is copy and paste. There is no reason to hunt certain wildlife. the game instead rewards you more for avoiding them, since they are never dropping something noteworthy. Wildlife always feels like as if they were just spawned into the world. scorpions and deathclaws have their environments that they spawn in but they dont feel like as if they 'did' anything. ANYTHING. In the sidequests you frequently meet people who dont tell you the truth. I found that to be a feature with potential. But in general most quests give the feeling like as if they were ment to be 'funny'. Funny quests would be ok/good if they were part of a wider spectrum of quest characters in general. But beeing just 'funny' as they are, the whole game feels underperforming. In a hostile world i want to find scary things. Bad guys do bad things, do they? Well ok , you can stop slavers and an evil organization from doing their evil things but it has no real effect on the world. The biggest achievement in the world is to generate purified water. Ok, its something relevant in this world. but aside from that? I cant think of a place that was flourishing up after me having cleared out the bad guys there.  If you want a game for your kids enjoyment, buy them Fallout 3. If you want a serious shooter in a hostile world, get Stalker - Shadow of Chernobyl or Clear Sky.

Ok, let's get the bad points out of the way first. It's not a massively difficult game, it has an annoying level-cap, the graphics suffer from occasionally horrendous pop-up and it's still as buggy as hell. Of course, modifying the hell out of the game can solve all but one of these issues, but for the vanilla version, these problems really SHOULD put people off of buying this (if they already haven't, of course!)  BUT! (and this is a massive Rosie O'Donnel size but!) none of these faults prevent this from being one of the most enjoyable and immersive games of the last decade. The game is huge. That's not an understatement - even without the add-ons, Fallout 3's world is staggeringly huge. The sheer volume of quests available will ensure lastability, and i'm not even counting the multitude of tiny little side-quests that don't pop up in your quest status. I'm on my 9th play-through of the GotY (I bought this originally on the *cough* 360, in early 2007 - in fact, this game was my sole reason for buying the console) and i'm still discovering new areas and little details that i'd never previously seen.  It offers multiple ways to play - you can blast everything that moves, you can talk your way through a large bulk of the quests here, you can be a sanctimonious goody-two-shoes, as neutral as a Swiss wastelander, or be as evil, scuzzy and downright Lucifer-like as you please. The array of weapons, armour and equipment at your disposal is second only to its lesser 'sequel'. I know many people prefer New Vegas, but personally I felt that something was lost. Maybe it was all the greenery, the copious amounts of insects, the weapon/ammunition modification options (which I found, for the most part, more intrusive than useful - just give me guns and ammo and show me where to point!) Don't get me wrong, New Vegas is wonderful in it's own way, but to me it's still Fallout 3's younger and not-quite-as-clever sibling.  This really is a must-have title for fans of RPG's - a truly landmark title, which is a phrase I use sparingly - and i've been gaming for 31 years. If you haven't played it, climb out from under that rock and get it. If you have, stop nodding in agreement, and go play it again!

Where do I begin?   Fallout 3 has to be one of the very best post-apocalyptic RPGs I have  ever  played in my entire 16 year-old life, and this does not go without reasoning.  From the moment you step out of the Vault (or the moment you're   pushed out of your momma  , because yes - that happens in-game.), to the moment you pick up the  Experimental MIRV  and loudly exclaim  'I run this ♥♥♥♥.' , Fallout 3 is nothing but solid 24k gold.  Fallout 3 came out in late 2008, about 6 years ago. Should this affect the way you look at the game? Not one bit. Sure, the engine might be a tad outdated, the texture department may have pulled a bit of a shorter straw compared to other aspects, but none of this means this game is worth passing up.  Now, the game might not be for everyone, but Bethesda definitely made an effort in assuring that each aspect of the game is well rounded, and that each player can find a play style that suits them - and when I say that, I truly mean it. There are a lot of games that for instance will tell you that you can choose how you want to play, but then in the end will penalize you for playing a certain way. (Hitman: Absolution comes to mind, even though I love that game.) Fallout 3 is  not  one of these games.  While your choices aren't as radically diverse as in Fallout: New Vegas, you can still choose whether you want to be a good guy, a little  across the board , or just straight up vile, and it does this really well. No matter where you go, what you do, the game never fails to present you with both good and bad choices. You want to defuse a large nuke that sits right in the center of a wasteland settlement? Do it. You want to attach an explosive device to that same nuke, travel halfway across the wastes, and watch the town go  boom  as you enjoy a nice cold Nuka-Cola in the setting sun? Go right ahead.  All in all, everything from the amazing tone and setting of the game, to the hilarious yet somehow extremely well-fitting music you can find on the in-game radio station(s), Fallout 3 captivates you like no other. If you're feeling like going on an epic post-apocalyptic adventure, and can afford to dish out the €19.99 (or €9.99 for the regular version with no DLC), I suggest you do so.  Fallout 3 is a game that should not be missed for anything in the world, so try not to.   10/10

War. War never changes. Fallout 3 does everything right and so much more. This role-playing, post-apocalyptic nightmare has hundreds of hours of content to be played. So what is it about? Before the war against China, underground vaults were made so civilization could continue in the event of a nuclear warhead exploding. Which is exactly what happened. You are from Vault 101 where you are to live and die. Obviously, this doesn't happen as your father escapes the vault and you search after him. The first quality to notice about this game is its size. The amount of quests, locations to discover, and the size of the map is simply huge. What makes this game so great is so many gameplay elements coming together so smoothly and harmoniously. This game is an RPG at its heart but includes first-person shooter qualities and is a huge action/adventure game at the same time. You level up, loot, find awesome guns, discover, and complete quests at your leisure. Of course, I can't not talk about the feature VATS, or the Vault-Tec Assisted Targetting System, which is awesome. You can pause the gameplay and pick what part of your enemy to attack with a given percentage of a chance to hit your target. It plays out in cinematic bullet-time and is simply really enjoyable. There's too much to be said about Fallout 3 due to its size that I can't cover it all. Instead, I'll end this by stating that this is my favorite game of all time. Buy it.
