Fallout 3: Tunnel Snakes Rule  Although we all knew it was there hiding behind the curtain, it’s nice to finally know that Fallout 4 is, indeed, a real thing. And, surprisingly. coming this year at that! With the recent announcement, I thought I would write about one of my favorite Bethesda games, Fallout 3.  I think it’s safe to say that for many of us, Fallout 3 was our first introduction to the series as a whole. Not to say that Fallout 1 and 2 were not popular games, but being the fourteen-year-old I was in 2008, it’s easy to believe many gamers like myself were introduced to the series with Bethesda’s take on the famous franchise.  Going from an isometric turn-based RPG to a first person “shooter” is definitely a massive sea change. Although I wasn’t invested, I remember hearing some people were disappointed in the changes that a first-person perspective brought (and I can totally understand why), but Fallout 3 is still a game that I look back on, seven years later, with wonderfully fond memories.  One of the things, I think, that made Fallout 3 great was that while the world was rather vast and empty, that feeling of “emptiness” was very fitting for a world ravaged by nuclear war. There were pockets of life and activity, and you would randomly stumble across creatures or bandits out in the wilderness, but it wasn’t exactly “dense”. The game struck a nice balance between you finding encounters, and encounters finding you. It always seemed like, given enough time and walking, something interesting would happen. Whether it was being attacked by horrible Super Mutants in Downtown Washington, or stumbling upon a homestead that has seceded from what is left of the government.  The world had flavor. And that made it fun to explore.  Much like it’s predecessor, TES IV: Oblivion, Fallout 3 had a rather... ‘off’ feeling to it. Which was, in some ways, a great contrast to the bright 50’s aesthetic of the game world. While at the same time fitting for its post apocalypse setting. There was a nice conflict between what the world “was” and what it had become.  In Fallout 3, it felt like just about every abandoned home you entered had some kind of tragedy waiting to be discovered. Whether it was the remains of a family scattered through a home, or a suicide note left by a survivor. There were so many little details tucked away in the various places of the D.C. Wasteland. These touches made the world feel “lived in.”  Aside from the general “lived in” quality that Fallout 3 had, there were plenty of disturbing moments which were hidden in the world too. Walking into a school that had been taken over by cannibals, and seeing their “food supply” strewn across the floor… Exploring downtown and being ambushed by horrible mutants. Investigating a murder, committed by wannabe vampires… And of course, going down into some of the abandoned Vaults hidden in the wasteland… For a game made by a company notorious for stiff game design. There were some very good moments in the game, whether scripted or not.  For instance, Vault 108 was very memorable for me because it was full of Garys.  Gary had been cloned, many, many times, his clones were insane and hostile to all non-Garys. Eventually the Garys killed everyone else in the Vault, causing it to fall into disrepair. It was unsettling to walk into the silent rusted hallways of the Vault, only for the silence to be shattered by gunfire and unrelenting battlecry of: “Gaaarrrryyyyy? Gaaaarrryyy!!!!” And having three madmen, or truthfully three of the same madman, trying to rip your throat out.  Bethesda used the isolation in many of the Vaults to great effect. I specifically remember Vault 87. A crusty, dilapidated Vault, filled with Super Mutants and Centaurs. The isolation, the oppressively low ceiling and close walls. Combined with the darkness, large amounts of human remains, and the overall nastiness of the enemies made for a very memorable experience. When the game was new, I remember playing through this area at two in the morning. While I was slowly making my way through the tense halls of the Vault, a dog started barking outside. I remember peering through the blinds trying to figure out what was going on... Before I realized the game had stressed me out and I was reacting to the stress.  But nothing came close to the Dunwich building, although it wasn’t the scariest thing in the game, it was certainly the most upfront about it. In most cases the tension was due to thinking you’re alone in a quiet, dark, place and suddenly being shot or attacked by monsters. However, the Dunwich building had special scripting for its events. There was nothing like it in the rest of the game, and I think that’s why it was so memorable. It was a little, creepy, gem left to be discovered. Uncovering what happened to the people there was very interesting and, simultaneously, off putting with a wonderfully creepy easter egg waiting for you at the end. I highly recommend checking it out.  Well done, Bethesda.  While the world of Fallout was certainly fun to explore and become familiar with, the mechanics of the game itself were, unfortunately, pretty clunky. Shooting was stiff, and in some cases felt quite weak. There was nothing worse than shooting someone in the head, getting a bad damage roll, and watching them shrug off a bullet like it was a spit ball.  However, what made the shooting in Fallout memorable was V.A.T.S. or, the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System.  This is the mechanic that made Fallout 3 for me, V.A.T.S. allowed you to pause time and select individual parts of your opponents, then shoot said targets. Plus, V.A.T.S. would show your shots in amazing slo-mo cinematic glory! It made the combat feel pretty epic. There was nothing better that blasting an annoying NPC in the face with a shotgun, watching their head fly apart in slo-mo, and then reloading your previous save to continue on.  “This Moriarty guy is infuriating…” *quick save* *murder* *quick load*  Seeing your dude shoot at the enemy, watching the killing bullet travel from the gun barrel into their head, and seeing it explode into a chunky red mist all from a cinematic camera angle was… satisfying...  Throwing a grenade into a group of bandits running at you with murderous intentions, seeing it sail through the air, land at their feet, and then watching their feet fly in six different directions was… satisfying…  Running up to a guard, punching him to death, and watching his body explode into little chunks because of the perk “bloody mess” was… hilarious…  Unfortunately, V.A.T.S. didn’t completely circumvent the clunky nature of the game, but it did make it tolerable, and in many ways wonderfully endearing. V.A.T.S. was, by far, my favorite part of Fallout 3 It was, and still is, a unique and interesting mechanic, that spiced up combat. And the idea of using it in the upcoming Fallout 4 is getting me hyped.  And hype is bad, hype is the game killer.  Now, as you may or may not know, Bethesda games are famous for being incredibly moddable. They come with a complete suite of tools used solely for the purpose of creating new original content for the game itself. Fallout 3 is no exception.  There are some amazing Fallout 3 mods floating around out there… and some really weird ones. If you feel like the game is missing something, chances are someone made a mod for it. Just be warned… There are a lot of… “adult” mods too. But, hey, if that’s your thing... They got your back!  The modding communities for Bethesda games are spectacular, there are some great gems out there on the internet. Sometimes you just gotta do some digging to find them. Just go in with an open mind, remembering that the game is from 2008, and expect some amount of ‘jank’ and you’ll be fine.  It might look and feel dated, but damn there’s a fine game in there.

I'm scrounging for 'story-rich' with playable graphics, large time investment, and action/fighting along the way. And by 'story-rich' I don't mean the let's read an interactive picture book indie dime-a-dozen thingy that's peppered all over Steam these days. I'd beg someone to shoot me now, in the forehead, before going there. By 'story rich', I mean complex with different endings and snappy dialogue and voice acting (see Dragon Age. Or Neverwinter nights 2. Or even Mass Effect). Yes, the higher budget stuff.  Fallout 3 had a 'story-rich' tag so I gave it a shot. It's not 'story rich.' Ok, so child seeking parent via various foiled quests and vice-versa is a time-honored plot device to be sure, but this is not in the scale of epic adventure of the parenthetically named games above. I never considered Skyrim to be 'story rich' either.  The detail here was good. The plausibility of some of the human crazy made it less pretty than Skyrim (same makers, very familiar engine and first person perspective) but so much better. Strange religions? Dog eat dog world? Clean water as a prime motivator? Sure. Hell, skirmishes and even wars were fought over water throughout history.   The voice acting was terrible. Not quite on the bad side of good like the original Resident Evil cheeseball writing, just plain bad. With 2 men and women voicing the entire thing and a silent protag (always bad) it's hard not to slide down that side of the bell curve.   Dialogue option win. I really do like getting the option of saying 'F you', twice, to someone. It can be cathartic in some cases, especially this game given main plot events. After all, there are times when an F bomb is the only right answer.  The radio bit was a great immersive detail. Travelling in and out of range of various radio towers, different channels giving different style news. Radio static. Old timey music as a soundtrack.......'Set the world on fire' in a post nuclear wasteland? Nice.  And the humorous commentary on the food that would somehow survive 200 years. Frozen salisbury steak, spam, and bottled Coke. Sure. Why not? I just want to know where all the twinkies got off to ala Homer Simpson.  Three words: giant naked molerats.  I only explored about a 3rd of the map. I find sandboxes tiresome, boring, and repetitive (and lacking in plot motivators). As much as I wanted to be completionist about it, I could not. So I jumped to the end and won. Yay me for saving the day. Main plot done, I'm done because the prime motivator is gone, but you can go off and explore and complete as many side quests as you like after. Though why you'd want to...  Even so, recommended overall. As ugly as a post nuclear landscape is I found this one much more compelling than elder scrolls and I fully intend to purchase the Fallout 4 after they issue the first patch.

NOTE: I already have a couple of hundred hours in F3 on my Xbox.  This is without doubt one of the all-time RPG classics. Reimagining the seminal post-apocalyptic setting of the old top-down Fallout games in the immersive open-world, first-person style of Bethesda games (the Elder Scrolls series), Fallout 3 is a rich and engaging experience. It's the only game I've played that starts your character's story arc with his/her own birth (tastefully but effectively executed). The opening then moves through a few key stages of his/her upbringing in the oppressive safety of an underground Vault before bringing that little world down around your ears and kicking you into the Wasteland. An innocent abroad, you make your way across post-apocalypse Washington, D.C. (and some of the surrounding region) in search of your disappeared father, and find adventure, danger, a host of colorful characters, and, hopefully, new purpose along the way.  The Vault prologue is somewhat slow, but extremely effective and rarely altogether tiresome. The Wasteland is colorful and impactful, its artfully reimagined and humorously upbeat 1950s-retro feel deliberately and powerfully clashing with its ruined and dilapidated state. New societies sway you - in person and over radio waves - to join their ranks while mutated creatures and sadistic bandits hunt you in the lawless hills. Small towns and conclaves dot the wastes, each with its own troubles and agendas, and a gratifying variety of retro-sci-fi armaments protect you in the spaces between. The D.C. ruins, while especially hazardous, are phenomenal in their stylized recreations of real-world landmarks ranging from presidential monuments to reimagined exhibits in the Smithsonian museums, and also, connecting this decrepit honeycomb, the metro system. The DLC expansions add new flavors to the play scape, between them including the snowy mountains of Alaska, an atmospheric coastal swampland, and, of all things, a huge alien spaceship. Have fun!  Naturally, the game isn't perfect. For most of your play time, regular scuffles with identical three-man mercenary hit squads follow you everywhere you go. The gunplay lacks iron-sight aiming (added in the sequel, Fallout: New Vegas) and relies in large part on calculations based on character skill level, which is fine for a straight-up turkey shoot, but can get a little aggravating when your carefully aimed sniper shot misses its large Super Mutant target and gives away your position. The monochromatic aesthetic can start to drag after a certain number of hours, the main storyline needs to be staged more carefully, and the area map lacks sufficient landmarks to find your destination very quickly when fast-traveling (all points also improved in New Vegas). But these mostly amount to quibbles - the game's great. If you like this sort of thing, stop waffling and buy it.

I cannot even add up the number of hours I have played Fallout 3. Across the PS3 and PC I have played and beaten this SO MANY FREAKING TIMES and still love it. There is just so much to do. Want to discover every location? be prepared to spend many, many hours doing so. But also be prepared to kill a lot of ants, mutants and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in the process, looting each one anc selling their left over crap to buy better gear and replnish your ammo. Fell like surviving a difficult, post apocalyptic experience? There is a gameplay mode that will force you to drink water and sleep regularly. Just want to run aroung causing mayhem? Oh, that's an easy choice to make and a highly enjoyable one. You can pick which factions you want to ally with and spend your time building your reputation and karma with them to the point that you and they are best friends, or you can just ♥♥♥♥ everyone off and loot the entire world. It's your call.  And that's really what this game is about. You can do whatever you want, really. You can pickpocket and murder all the civilians you meet or you can do favors for them. Either way will get you access to bottlecaps and gear. You can collect all the NukaCola's to turn in later, or drink them as you go.  You can create your own weapons from recipes that you find/steal around the Washington DC area. Weapons like a lawnmower blade which is also on fire. Or a 'launcher' which uses the random crap you find all over the place as ammo and launches it at enemies. Ever feel like killing a mutant with teddy bears, toy cars and baseballs? Yup, this is the weapon for you.  There are large flies, wild dogs, bears, mutants, clam-men, large scary-looking beast with claws, good soldiers, neutral soldiers, evil soldiers, zombie-looking people, good bounty hunters, evil bounty hunters, slave traders, travelling merchants, vampires and more. Pick your side (if you want to) and good hunting!

Obviously I am fairly late to the game. Over the years I have read many a description on this game detailing its amazing satirical discussion on nationalism and propaganda. Finally, I have delved far enough to see what this talk was about. Indeed, never have I been subject to such a quality, subtle look into such profound concepts in a medium such as this.  The moment I stepped out of the vault and picked up that signal, Enclave Radio, I realized the incredible, obvious truth that has been staring us all in the face. The truth that we have been blind to, that has been filtered away by the media, that we touch on in tired history classes, only to forget as the tests come and go.  We are no longer true patriots of this great and mighty United States of America.  I stayed in Springville for hours on end listening to the eyebot echo the words of my pip boy, the words of that prophet... No... President, John Henry Eden. The only time I faultered was when I could break away from my computer screen long enough to realize that it was a new day and that I needed to renew my pledge of allegience. Eventually, only after being thoroughly certain that my pip boy would carry those great words, those chilling calls to action, no matter where I went, I did progress into the game.  And progress I did. Through a series of mistakes I somehow found myself in support of the Brotherhood of Steel, a confused group who I was only associating with in hopes of opening their eyes of the glory of the new government they simply didn't understand. Oh, but there was no mistake, was there? Not as soon as I had the glorious opportunity to lay eyes and ears on the greatest achievement the United States could hope to replicate: Liberty Prime.  I will not spoil things for my fellow patriots, to give them the chance of self discovery that I had. But let me promise you that not a day has gone by that I haven't spent readying my homemade mini nukes in preparation for the forthcoming final war against communism, painting them in the sacred color pallette of Red White and Blue as I sing the National Anthem and hum to the tunes between the Enclave Radio I have running 24/7, mounted proudly on my wall.   We may not be in an apocalypse that we can visibly see outside of our door, America, but we are without a doubt at risk of losing all that makes this country as free and superior as it is. Fallout 3 has shown me the truth. The Enclave, the Brotherhood, the great nuclear disaster... It is a message, encoded wisely into what so many regard as 'just a computer game.' And we must play that game. We must hear that message. And then we will know.  12/10, Could use a few bug fixes tho

When I first played this game and compared it to Fallout New Vegas, I thought this game was a shallow RPG, and part of me still does, but after playing Fallout 4 (the only fallout game on steam I gave a thumbs down to), I can now realize more about this game and appreciate it more. I would still recommend Fallout New Vegas over Fallout 3, but I recommend Fallout 3 over Fallout 4. Story: The story in this game is sort of good and bad. The story is very personal, related to your character, and sort of gripping, which I like. The games beginning is VERY memorable with a lot of explanation. Honestly, in the story part of this game, I think Fallout 3 has a good story, but what pisses me off is it is EXTREMELY linear, so its black and white style, and you cannot side with the evil faction. Other than that, the story is good. Overall (8/10) Gameplay: The gunplay in this game honestly is not very good. Most of the time, you will be using VATS. Another really annoying part of this game is there are very few side quests. 17 in total without dlc. 17!! A good amount of the side quests are pretty deep and detailed, which makes them fun to play, but the game gets boring pretty quick. The game is also incredibly easy. Deathclaws can be killed with combat armor and a 10mm pistol. Back to when I am comparing this game to Fallout 4, this game has a Karma system (which was ripped out in 4), which keeps track of the good or evil you have done. Certain companions can only be recruited with a certain type of Karma. Also, the level cap is pretty small, so you need to choose your SKILL POINTS AND PERKS wisely. Also, the dialogue system isnt pathetically bad like in Fallout 4. This allows for several character builds, which I really like. Weapons also have condition, so you need to keep your repair skill up. I also like the dlc in this game. The atmosphere in this game also captures the post apocalyptic feel very well in this game. One major annoyance is if you dont have the broken steel dlc, you cannot play after you beat the game. Its good that the dlc fixes it and you dont need a mod to do that. The main problem is that it just gets boring kinda fast. Overall (8/10) Perfomance: You read it on the steam page. Not optimized for Windows 7 and newer. This game is BROKEN. You will spend an hour downloading and another two to get it to work not even decently, just to load the game to the main menu without crashing. The game also crashes every 5 to 10 minutes. They should have patched this game to make it work properly, but nope. Overall (5/10) Final verdict: 8/10 If you have $20, I would recommend Fallout New Vegas if you want an RPG experience. I would buy Fallout 3 if you want a huge open world to explore. I would buy Fallout 4 if you want a casualized and dumbed down version of both Fallout 3 and New Vegas, and if you like Borderlands with all of the humor in it taken out.
